title: Staff gave me my full medical records
body: I have asked for my full medical records from my former NHS Dr Surgery in Kent on several occassions in the past and I got nothing much back. I really needed this record. This time I asked my Epsom GP and I was given a complete and comprehensive record going back to my birth. This was delivered securely on a data disk.   It was really great to feel listened to and that someone in my new Drs could be bothered to get that information for me in an orderly and helpful way, as I had asked. Thanks you so much for doing this diligent work at this time.  It makes me feel valued.

title: Excellent practice
body: The doctors, nursing and reception staffs are very good and efficient during the hard times of Covid-19, I always use the mail and digital system or sometimes by phone their response is prompt. They’re very caring and their approaches are very professional. We’re proud to have them here in Chelsfield

title: Wonderful staff
body: Went for a blood test and flu jab today, all the staff are helpful, compassionate and always put you at ease.  I had a question whilst I was there and another member of staff who happened to come into all of you are a credit to the NHS!!

title: Great care and a tension
body: Excellent . Care from start to to finish . All staff in all areas from . The times I got in the ambulance. To A.E to  resus And then one to the ward . Sometimes hear how understaff they are and had a problem but overall excellent care could not have a better .thank you nhs

readBy.name: University Hospitals Coventry and Warwickshire NHS Trust

title: Great staff
body: Thank you to every one in the pain clinic for your kindness shown to me last week I was told every thing they were doing to me from the consultant nurses and admin staff once again a big thank you couldn’t have been better if it was private,

title: Friendly & helpful
body: Joined here in the middle of the Coronavirus outbreak and they have been great. Majority of the reception team are lovely & so helpful. I've only ever had one slightly rude encounter with one particular receptionist but ever since I've had no issue. Doctors are also very caring & take time to listen to you unlike previous GP's who make you feel rushed. Have had a few minor issues with getting through on the phone lines later in the day but suspect this is due to short staffing with COVID19. I work in a practice myself and understand the stress & abuse all staff face so just a reminder that you are a great team & we are very grateful for you all.

title: Children's Ward - A Fab team
body: My daughter came into the children's ward on the 18th November 2020 for blood tests. The staff were fantastic, from the student nurse who took her blood pressure to the Nurse and Advanced Practitioner who took her blood. They put her at ease, took her blood without fuss and kept her relaxed throughout. A great team, a credit to the hospital.

readBy.name: North Cumbria Integrated Care NHS Foundation Trust

title: A completely assuring experience
body: I’m not one to leave reviews unless totally compelled to do so. Today I visited the Breast Clinic for the first time. I was anxious, worried. The entire team were superb in their handling. I felt comforted, understood and they made me feel like I mattered. The service was super efficient yet totally comforting. Thank you to every single member of that team.

title: Good Surgery and Friendly Staff
body:
Thank you again for a happy professional  and kind experience at my appointment today . I always find the Reception and Medical Staff do their very best to ensure your medical needs are met and with a nice friendly approach and try their best to help you .
Thank you Station Practice

title: Great team
body: I visited the A&E at Salisbury hospital in rather unpleasant circumstances but the staff has been great at dealing with my situation. I was also surprised to see night time cleaners as the place was very clean and tidy. I noticed the nurses were very happy to have them as it was a very busy night over there. I was moved to Farley ward very soon and was told it use to take very long but it has changed since they have night cleaning staff. Big thank you to the whole team, very friendly and pleasant nurses, and to the cleaning team who was working very hard!

author: Upset22
title: I didn't really feel like they listened
body:
I was advised by GP to attend A& E due to severe chest pain especially as I had a 24hr ecg tape that concerned them. The HCA assistant was great and caring. But the doctor I didn't really feel like they listened to me properly and they ultimately put the issue down to anxiety.  
I waited over an hour for a nurse to find my notes to get painkillers organised when I was in so much pain I didn't know how to deal with it. And when I tried to tell another nurse I felt worse they said they would tell the doctor but walked away not knowing my name or my doctor and sat down speaking to another nurse instead.  
The doctor when they discharged me the told me I am not to attend the department again unless I'm having classic heart attack symptoms. But heart attacks can be very varied? ! Yet when I was in A& E a few weeks ago for similar issue the cardiologist saw me and told me to come back if I get worse symptoms. This made the experience poor.

author: Elaine1589
title: The nurse was so rude to myself and others
body:
In November 2020. I was unexpectedly admitted to crosshouse hospital with severe abdominal pain. Unfortunately I still have this and nothing was done except bloods, urine and CT scan.  
Two days after my admission I had the pleasure of meeting a nurse on the ward who was so rude and nasty to myself and other patients on the ward. Once I decided to go for a walk to the lifts and back, but before I could get to the doors of the ward they shouted at me, asking where the f### do I thought I was going. I told her I was simply going to stretch my legs as they are sore. The nurse shouted back at me, telling me to get back to my f###in bed right now or they would pour ice cold water over me. I was appalled at what they had just said to me. No wonder some consultants on the ward turned around.  
A nurse is there to look after vulnerable patients and to help them get well etc, not to make them feel small and unsafe. I saw the nurse in question do this to many patients on that day that it's bang out of order.  
All the other nurses on this ward deserve a medal as I can't fault them. Even through the covid pandemic.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: scoopyoiseau
title: Recent experience
body:
Hello,  
I visited Nuffield Orthopaedic Centre for a face - to - face appointment in the outpatients department. I don't want to start with the carparking but I will - the payment pods weren't taking card payments only cash (tricky during a cashless covid!) and being cashless and with the card machine in the foyer out of service I had to park without paying - sorry about that. I think they've only been accepting cash for a few weeks so advance warning in the letter might be a good idea.  
The lady who worked on the outpatient booking desk in the foyer and the gentleman on the desk in the outpatient department were very polite and helpful showing me where to go.  
The Dr who my appointment was with was also great - good communication, very polite, asked if i had any questions and told me what would happen next.  
The only real negative was overhearing two staff members at a desk next to the seating area talking about a patient one of them had just seen which included detail of the test and how the patient wasn't right about something. I know staff need to talk about patients but perhaps if the conversation is going to include detail of how a patient was being a little bit awkward this shouldn't be done next to a seating area for other patients to overhear. Certainly made me feel like I wouldn't want to be seen by them if they were then going to discuss me in an open area afterwards.

author: Qwerty16
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Mistakes can be made
body:
One member of staff who's attitude is not good. No respect to me.
Sometimes room is cold.
Would like a fully trained member of staff to visit along with students as mistakes can be made.
Be listened to more and what patient has to say.
No remotes for TVs

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Johan Barr
title: Pulmonary rehabilitation provision during the pandemic
body:
I have emphysema, severe enough to require home oxygen. I require to have done a pulmonary rehabilitation course in order to qualify for assessment for lung volume reduction treatment.  
Understandably these courses can no longer be taken in person. However the service at PRI has continued virtually. Unfortunately the criterion for accessing this requires the patient to attend the physiology department in PRI in person for assessment.  
I live alone and my car is out of action. I would therefore be required to find someone willing to take me at a time when the scottish government advice is that there should be no car sharing with individuals from separate households.  
I have explained that as a person in the shielding category I am not prepared to take this risk and was told that I may not take advantage of the course.  
The respiratory nurse service is prepared to make home visits to patients in my situation and it is not clear why the physiology department cannot do the same and is apparently happy to put vulnerable patients at risk..

author: Blood hound
title: Outpatients long term care
body:
I have a cancer diagnosis and am on what is referred to as Active Surveillance. This is ongoing for 2 to 3 years.  
This year, I have felt that I needed to ask when my next routine Appointment was going to happen. Twice since late July I have simply phoned to enquire about my next 'planned' appointment and twice things have happened immediately. Well, as immediately as things happen in the NHS.  
I appreciate that Covid has had a major impact on NHS services and I would have been happy to have been told that my appointment was already in the pipeline but no, on checking, it was agreed that I was due an appointment and one has duly been arranged in reasonable timescales.  
This last time after and MRI In mid August I had heard nothing regarding the MRI results by early November. It turns out that as a result of the MRI, I now need a small procedure.  
I'm left wondering, 1 What triggers a review of the MRI results? 2 How long would I have waited if I had not enquired?  
With Covid taking up many hospital beds, will my procedure be delayed, will that have a negative impact on my health and what is the likelihood of catching Covid while at the hospital ??  
My resolution going forward is not to sit back and wait but to simply ask.

author: Shawf48
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: on behalf of a carer/ care received from Working Age Sevice and IRIS Ashfield Team
body: Brilliant service, you’ve really helped me (Carer) and my wife a lot, especially me as I wouldn’t have known what I needed to do, about everything. I knew if I’d got any issues I could ring and you would support and guide me the right way. Introducing my wife and myself to the peer hub was great, she so enjoys her time with the others.”

links.id: dementia working age dementia and peer support

author: couragene79
title: Mobile Theatre Eye Operation
body: I had an operation in March to tighten the muscles in my eye, this was done in a mobile theatre in the car park at Hairmyres Hospital, East Kilbride, I think this was due to the amount of backlog patients awaiting surgery (day patients)When I walked in I was greeted by one of a few nurses, there was only about 6 patients in the place, I have to say it was one of the best experiences I've had re operations, the atmosphere was warm and made me feel so comforable, the nurses as normal were fantastic at putting all at ease, the consultants came to us to talk over procedures, the operation was great and I was able to go home soon after, I felt I had to report my "happy"time there, A huge thank you to all who made us all comforable and at ease and....fixing us

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: backontrack
title: wisbech facilities
body:
Nothing but praise for the service and the team @CGL Wisbech, which I'll post about separately.  
However, although there is an option to connect to WiFi as CGL guest it's not working - seems to allow you to register but no confirmation sms/email received with username & pw. Please remedy.  
(Apparently it's not worked for ages, if ever. If so please remove the option !)

author: Vijaya
title: To become an employee
body: I got the job with the support of the team

author: Moore000
title: I attended the OTAP department at Forth Valley Hospital Larbert, Scotland
body: After spending the night in Critical Assessment I attended the OTAP day care for a week getting an IV drip every day. I found the staff and doctor very attentive, and supportive. They explained what they were doing and why. They were very approachable.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

links.id: drip blood test for dvt tissue viability nurse

title: Appalling admin & No rush to send out…
body:
Attended the Reading Healthharmonie location on Friday 13th. Ophthalmologist advised prescription would be with my GP for the Saturday.  I spoke with my GP on the Monday and when they called me back later that day said they had not have the prescription request. Its now Wednesday, I have made 3 calls to HH. Called HH Tuesday morning and the first person wasn't even going to check my records the and just said the letter takes 2 days to get to the GP, when I pushed him to look at my notes he said there was an issue with the request and would email a manager to have it sorted and I would have a call back later that day. Second call on the Wednesday morning went through the info again as there was no update gave the email address and receptionist name at my GP and she said she would email this to a manager and would have it sorted. Haven't heard anything back at 3.30 (third call) and spoke to a lady who couldn't find the email address or info I provided earlier and said maybe the person I spoke to earlier had a different system she used so that's why she couldn't find the information. She said a letter had been sent and would take 2 days to get to my GP as the letters are sent second class ** they are prescriptions so why are they being sent by letters at all what about email **. I said that's not good enough I need the prescription as I have an allergic reaction that I need the meds for. She also said I would get a call back and the lady in question did call me back to confirm the prescription was being emailed today.
Its taken 5 days to get a prescription and 3 calls.  
HelathHarmonie are not providing the type of service I am sure the NHS are paying for. 
Lets see if my GP does get the prescription request.

author: caringgk48
title: Thank You to the NHS
body:
During the evening of 18th September 2020 I was admitted to the Emergency Department at Wishaw General Hospital. A very kind and caring Ambulance Team had come to my rescue at my home in Rigside, near Lanark. They had found me lying on the concrete in my back yard. I had fallen from a very high step ladder whilst collecting elderberries. On arrival at hospital I became aware that I was broken in mind, body and spirit.  
It was Dr Ryan who first looked after me. Having refused pain relief in the ambulance Dr Ryan soon sorted me out. After visiting the Xray Department it was Dr Ryan who explained exactly how many bones I had broken. I remember saying that I had to go home because I had so many pets which relied on me. He explained that if I wasn’t treated I would most likely never walk again. I got the message.  
What happened to me through that first night is very hazy. Various procedures were carried out and I only remember feeling terribly thirsty and not understanding why I couldn’t have a drink of water. I have no idea when I was eventually taken to Ward 15.  
I have a very bad memory of my time on Ward 15, not because of my own pain but because of a fellow patient who persisted in howling out her pain constantly. This howling, crying and screeching was truly unbearable. In fact, when I was being prepared to go to theatre early on Sunday morning I couldn’t wait to go to get some peace. I was later to learn from other patients that they’d suffered the same fate on Ward 15.  
The operations went well and thanks to an incredible team in the theatre I was blissfully unaware of whatever procedures were performed on me. I was taken from there to the ACCU (Adult Crisis Care Unit). I soon became very frightened indeed as wires and tubes were attached to me and the pain built and built into total agony. This was when my mental state began to deteriorate. The fear gave me the strong impulse to flee. I remember, especially during the night, pulling out tubes and wires to free myself so that I could escape. My bed was close to the nurses station and they were ever alert to my antics.  
I’m not sure which night it was but I just wanted it all to end and called out for help to kill myself. This turned out to be my turning point. Someone looked into my eyes and told me severely that I wasn’t going to die. I began to accept my situation and begin the process of allowing the medical professionals to heal me.  
Day by day life on the extremely busy ward became easier. I soon began to feel overwhelmed by the kindness shown to me by one and all. I became an observer and watched, with great fascination, as each team seemingly danced through their 12 hour shifts. Every team member both smiled and laughed as they tackled their enormous workload. The atmosphere on the ward was so very special.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland
North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership
South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

title: Unprofessional
body:
Got called today for phone appointment. 
What a unprofessional doctor he was, rude uncaring and totally portentous.
What doctor says what do you want me to do about it????? Totally disgusting if he doesn’t care why are you a doctor, shame because other doctors there are brilliant.
What a let down

title: Great Family Practice
body: Always get great treatment here. Staff are friendly and knowledgable. No complaints about the treatment I have received.

title: Great care
body:
Dear Surgery,
I am writing to say very many thanks for the care the surgery has given me over the past few months. I could not have wished to be in better hands and thank you for everything.

title: Efficient practice with friendly staff
body: Have always been seen quite promptly with only a short wait time.  The dentist & the Hygenist , are very qualified and capable and have a kind gentle manner.  The nurse for women’s issues is also very gentle.  I’ve only recently had telephone consultations with the doctor but the call came on time, she gave me enough time, listened well, and advised well.  A nice well run practise I recommend.  Sometimes you have to hang on along time on the phone to speak to them but do be patient.

title: Excellent Pracfice
body:
I have been with this practice for a number of years and every time I am greeted with lovely smiles and warm welcomes from both receptionists and doctors and nurses. I have always felt welcomed there and always been pleased with the care I received.
I have been recently for blood tests and the Nurse was amazing, kind, and caring. She has a great sense of humour and always make me laugh. She makes it all comfortable and was quick.
Thank you to all the staff at the Practice. Continue to keep up the appreciated care.

title: Lovely staff
body: I recently registered at this surgery and the staff could not have been nicer. I was able to register really quickly, and book an appointment for the following week. I spoke to a couple of different receptionistson the phone and both were friendly and helpful. They listened to me, answered all of my questions, and talked me through the processes that I would need to use. I have a longterm medical condition and was really worried about changing doctors but I feel reassured that I've made a good choice in joining this surgery.

title: Nether great or bad practice
body: The people at reception are polite when you called however sometimes you called 8am in the morning and it’s such a long wait I had to hong up. I feel in my opinion that the people at reception they are the doctor, you’ve to explain everything to them about your illness before you go to  the next step or decided if you ill enough to see the doctor. Probably is what they ask to do I don’t know but it’s a joke and I feel if you do go to the next step  where you do see the doctor, they talk to you a minute if that and any results from the visit you may never hear the feedback unless you kept chasing it. I must highlight that they have good parking and it’s good that the pharmacy is next door if needed. I must also say I came across polite doctors and nurses.

title: Great practise
body: I just want to say this surgery is the best surgery our family have used. We always get to speak to someone about our ailment even if we dont get an appointment which is very rare in normal circumstances. I also want to say we appreciate everything the surgery are doing at this challenging time.Thank you to each and everyone of you who work here .

title: Online service
body:
Terrible. 3 times changed online website and now you can not find where is what. It is so complicated. Trying to log on silsdengrouppractise and screen showing message- SPLAT
Disgraceful.

title: Lucky to have such a good practice
body: I have never had anything but excellent service from the practice and I have been a patient there for over 30 years. If you ring in the morning you will usually be given a choice of appointment on the same day. During Covid, I rang with a problem and a GP rang me back twice before we decided I should go into the surgery for an examination. I was seen, diagnosed and treated later that same day. This is just one example I could give of many of how the practice is responsive to patients' needs. In addition, the GPs, practice and support staff are all professional and friendly. I feel extremely lucky that we have such a good practice at Honley.

author: FWIT
title: My recovery from alcoholism
body:
I was suffering from alcoholism. I tried to give up drinking earlier in 2020 and managed only 5 weeks of sobriety. I wanted to stop and I knew I needed support. I turned to One Recovery who were supportive from the world go. I was quickly appointed a keyworker, who listened to my situation. Just talking about it really helped.  
The time he gave me made me want to succeed, and provided the reassurance I needed to take action. My keyworker recommended certain tailored solutions which really worked for me. This involved talking to Healthy Minds and completing their Computer Based Therapy program which helped me deal with worries and anxieties related to my drinking. After about 8 weeks under their guidance, I no longer drink. I feel free from a problem which has plagued me for years. I now have my life back and I know I could not have succeeded without their support, and to whom I am eternally grateful.

links.id: worries and anxieties related to my drinking

author: Theboyandme87
title: Suffered badly with social anxiety and depression
body:
Though out my life I’ve struggled badly, it first started in my teens, then it progressed, I fell out with my parents and literally only had my nan and grandad for support. I had just gone through a divorce and come out of the other side of it. Found a new partner who took me and my son on, I used to be very short fused with mu little boy. but I still couldn’t shift the horrid feelings I had in my head. My nan become terminal Ill and I took it hard. I promised her I would get myself better, that’s where I started my journey with inclusion
I started talking to Ian in august, my first session I was a nervous wreck, I hated it I didn’t think there would be an end to these feelings I had. I kept with it, Ian listened and understood where I was coming from with certain situations in my life. I got brave started to make amends with my parents, with the help of Ian and my nan. I was getting better and stronger. Learning to look at situations in a different light. Then I lost my nan, the reason I started my journey, I took it badly and felt like giving up. With Ian’s reassurance and support I got through it, 8weeks after my nans passing I was back, better then before. Knowing I can’t give up. I think my sessions have taught me to look at things in a different light to breath and look at situations before making my decisions, yes it’s been hard, but I’m so glad I’ve done this journey in my life. I don’t feel like I carry worry as much as I did before. I now know how to deal with my head and not shout and loose my temper with my little one. I still suffer with anxiety and depression but I’ve learnt to deal with it using different techniques.

title: Terrible receptionist.
body: We rang today to ask what time our flu jab was. The receptionist was very unhelpful and rude. She asked my husband if he was sure I was disabled! We have been having flu jabs for years now. I asked about speaking to a doctor about medication as I am suffering with bad depression and again she was very unhelpful and rude. Not what you want to experience when suffering with bad mental health. She left both my husband and I upset and frustrated.  We have confirmation of our appointment yet she refused to accept we had made an appointment. This happened 20/11/2020 at 9 am.  She said she had to send a message to the manager to make sure we could book a flu jab despite us receiving a letter saying we should book one. I am extremely ill and my husband is my full time carer. We don’t need this kind of stress and do not deserve to be treated with sick rudeness and disrespect. I understand sometimes they need to ask certain things but to ask if he was sure I am disabled is disgusting and extremely disrespectful. Very unhappy with the service we have received today by this one receptionist. Usually we have a good experience with the staff. I’m not sure if she is new or just not trained properly.

title: Notgood
body:
I was taken off my meds and we end of a second lot to be out on new ones however
Not had new ones be is COVID started I phoned to day for appointment this morning to just be told no appointments left and phone back Monday my meds are for depletion anxiety and not had enny since then I know a lot is going on but your Heath is still important I didn’t to bother the Doctor cos of COVID  but the reception was not helpful at all

title: Flu Jab with nurse
body:
i booked an appointment for a flu jab for yesterday at 3.30pm.
I waited 5 weeks for the appointment and had to leave work early.
The nurse was very abrupt and asked me why i had booked one.
i said because i am 62, have high blood pressure and was very ill with the flu or covid in Jan/Feb.
You are not entitled to one, you are fit and healthy was the reply.
She was so abrupt that i came out almost in tears.
Why wasnt i told when i booked it that i was not entitled to it?
They even asked me my date of birth.
Did the nurse have to be so abrupt and rude??

title: Messed about twice
body: Have now been messed about twice at midwife appointments. Both times I got time off work to attend to then be told this morning oh didnt anyone phone you. Your appointment was cancelled. No one called me no one sent a letter- nothing. Very annoyed now missing time at work for no reason!!!!

readBy.name: Cambridgeshire And Peterborough NHS Foundation Trust

title: Negligent practice
body:
I accompanied my disabled wife to Liverpool Clatterbridge over a period of 3 months for both chemo and radiotherapy.
While the attitude of staff to patients, at every level, appears exemplary the approach to mask wearing during the pandemic is inexplicable. 
Many staff are clearly following recommended guidance but many are not.
Wearing masks under the nose or chin appears commonplace. We identified this in reception areas, amongst catering staff, health care assistants, a minority of porters and front line nursing staff, particularly location 63, chemo suite A.
During an entire day, on November 17th, two nurses and one health care assistant were not following protocols at all, wearing masks permanently under their noses or chins. Three more staff were only intermittently wearing masks correctly. The rest were perfect.
Yes we mentioned it to a nurse who said that she hadn’t noticed.
My wife complained to reception that the outside caterers were not wearing masks at all- to no effect. The staff in the new canteen are very slack indeed. Masks on and off, under their noses and so on.
The only department where we experienced consistency was radiotherapy. Excellent.
Given the covid situation in Liverpool this is all depressing.
It is clearly a systemic problem at Liverpool Clatterbridge and training in infection control, supervision and monitoring is needed to turn around what is, currently, completely unacceptable.

readBy.name: Wirral University Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Amazing care.
body: From the moment my surgery was booked in, the care I received was second to none, such a personal, caring, old school bedside manner. The whole team works as a family unit and I felt safe every step of the way through a rather daunting first surgery. Worries, expectations and outcomes were all spoken about and someone was at the end of the phone before and after surgery if needed. Even through the very worrying time of Coid-19, care and safety of everyone was a top priority. I cannot thank the staff enough, I am now pain free and the hardest part is making sure I do as I'm told and do not over do it!

title: Excellent Family oriented Practice
body:
I and all the members of my family have been registered at this practice since 2005 and in all these years, we have found the professionalism, care and dedication of the entire staff exemplerary.

Consulations are detailed and you always leave every appointment certain you have been listened to and  given the correct advice/treatment plan.

Every phone call is followed up and reminder calls re appointments, presciptions etc are always made.

title: Highly Efficient
body: Attended Stratford Hospital MRI Department for an early morning scan.  I was very impressed with the efficiency, courteousness and helpfulness of all the staff, particularly the Radiographer.  I was put at ease and did not experience any adverse reactions throughout the process.  Thank you for making this procedure as comfortable as possible.

title: no appointment
body: I have being trying all week to get ahold of Lakeside Medical Diagnostics  to book my ultrasound scan. I have not been into this practice yet and cant really give a review on the service inside the building as of yet. The phone rings and goes to an automated voice. The phone has not been answered once! I have received this telephone number by my GP practice Western Road surgery 01708 805141. I have also looked online for an alternative number but unfortunately there isnt one. I have no choice but to drive to the centre and try and speak to someone to book my appointment. Please can you look into this.

title: not happy
body: The reviews left seem very glowing but my experience (20years at this surgery) is not positive. I have felt completely unsupported all the way through my health problems, no desire to probe into health issues that have now been diagnosed elsewhere, a feeling of complete unwillingness to help. Never the same GP, impossible to get an appointment when you need it, etc. At my last visit, I was in so much pain I could hardly walk, met the GP (unknown to me) and told to get off the counter painkillers without her even checking my feet or history, you couldn't make it up. Not going there anymore as I find it a complete waste of time and always leaves me with a feeling of being completely unimportant.

title: Heros
body: I am so grateful once again to Harefield for looking after me. The kindness is nothing short of overwhelming.  In these Covid times they continue to take care of you.  God bless the NHS staff and all who work at the front line to be our guardian angels.  This is from the surgeons to the auxilliaries.  Bless you one and all.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

title: A&E via ambulance
body:
From the paramedics who came to get me to the wonderful staff and doctor in A&E very well done for a fantastic service.
Thank you all so very much.
Peter.

title: Neuropathic nerve clinic
body: I came September 2020 at 2 pm Sunday & still not received any information back to my surgery Hungerford Road Crewe regards my Carpal Tunnel  thank you

readBy.name: University Hospitals of North Midlands NHS Trust

title: Poor service
body: I tried 5 times today to speak to Pilgrim switchboard. On the 5th attempt a surly Scottish gentleman eventually answered the phone, with an attitude of what the hell do you want (words not used) This is the main switchboard for a large hospital and a little politeness would not go amiss.

title: Blood test.
body:
I need a Blood test,urgently according to my GP.
Church street practice only takes bookings for the day you ring.

Spent 40 minutes on hold Wednesday,got through all blood tests gone.

Thursday.  Ditto.
Friday.Ditto.

Due to personal reasons i cannot ring the surgery before 10am.

So it looks like i will have to wait till i am serious enough to be admitted to hospital before i get a blood test.

The reason given why you cant book blood tests in advance is of course Covid. 

But if i want to book a Flu jab for sometime next week,not a problem. 

Obviously the Flu is more important than my Cancer.

title: Really pleased with my care
body: I’ve been with Peverell for a few years. Recently I’ve been in touch with them regularly. Always can get through on the phone and they respond really quickly to e-consults. Very happy with their services and am happy to recommend to anyone looking for a good practice.

title: Lovely staff
body:
The staff were so lovely and friendly and hard-working. Everyone I came into contact with was kind and helpful and I felt very well looked after. 
There were very few patients there and so don’t be worried about Covid as it seemed very safe

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust

title: Exemplary
body: A member of the admin team was very helpful using E consult & making a same day appointment with a GP for me. Following the appointment, a referral to a consultant was made for me. I was seen within 8 days, resulting in a swift diagnosis & treatment. The efficient response, together with the care & kindness demonstrated towards me was exemplary. Thank you.

title: Lovely staff
body:
I was transferred from LRI to he Clinical Decisions Unit at Glenfield. Firstly, the ambulance staff were fantastic and even made sure I was ok once on the ward in my cubicle. I saw other paramedics being very kind to their patients also 
The staff on the CDU were so kind and helpful and I felt very well looked after and it was a very positive and thought-provoking experience. It showed me how the NHS staff are working so hard and always want the best for their patients in these difficult circumstances. Love ‘em!

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust

title: ‘Flu jab
body: Extremely efficient from being met at the door to receiving jab & departing. Despite it being 19.00 everyone was cheerful & welcoming.

author: Angeldust545
title: I wasn’t even examined
body:
I was advised to attend a and e by chemo nurses who were concerned about my pain and potential clots. Upon arrival to a and e I had to have my blood pressure, temperature and medical history taken in a busy waiting room.  
The nurse straight away went and got a consultant that asked why I was there as I have terminal cancer, saying they can’t fix me so it was pointless me being there. I said I was in pain and that needed addressing as I was uncomfortable. This Dr then proceeded to ask why I didn’t get my cancer seen to earlier and how rare my cancer is as I’m so young and to then remind me I’m palliative and there was nothing they could do with me.  
After having waited for over 30 minutes in the waiting room it was decided I should be isolated due to being in active treatment even though I had made that known upon my arrival.  
I was lead to a room with just a chair and left where a Dr then came in and changed their mind about my treatment 4 times. They had prescribed me a pain medication I was never brought, 3 hrs later they wanted to iv me a pain medication I’m already taking. I said there was no point as I was already taking that medication so they decided to write me a prescription for an increased dose and said I could go to Asda to collect it. I have never felt so sad and having stage 4 cancer is hard enough I don’t need to be constantly reminded of my fate.  
I went to Asda with my prescription to be told by the pharmacist they could not issue me with my medication as the script had 4 mistakes on including no dosage, no amounts and no frequency in which to take the drug. It also didn’t state on the script that it was a controlled drug. I was informed it would be illegal to prescribe me this drug due to the lack of information on the script.  
By this time it’s nearly 9pm and I decide to go home as I don’t want to go sit back in the crowded waiting room of the a and e department for them to rectify their mistake as I was exhausted and still in pain. I then had to call my gp the following morning to get a correct prescription issued. I wasn’t even examined to find the cause of my pain, which might not necessarily be the cancer.  
It was almost like I had been written off when I walked through the door. This experience now leaves me hesitant to attend there in the future for any of my care needs. A little sensitivity and respect would be wonderful. I wonder if they would say to an elderly person why are you here don’t you know how old you are and your probably going to die soon anyway because your old. So why as a person in their 30s who could have another 10+yrs with manageable treatment be treated this way?

title: Great practice and great doctor
body: Fantastic phone call consultation, gave me more information then what I have been given over the past 3 years for my medical problem. Would definitely recommend this doctor to all. Thank you very much for all advice and help today x

title: 5 Star treatment
body: Have just had my 1st cataract surgery at SpaMedica , The staff and surgeon were wonderful, so caring and put me at ease. There is nothing to be afraid of no pain or discomfort.

title: Outstanding care
body: I had and endoscopy  earlier this week and the care was outstanding. I was very nervous  and the staff in the unit were at all times professional, kind and empathetic. I had  to wait over two hours for my procedure to take place as there was a very complex case before me.  But the staff kept me up to date at all times which was very reassuring. A wonderful team thank you!

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Dreadful receptionists
body: Receptionists are rude and unhelpful. They treat you like you are an inconvenience and they shout out your personal details for everyone else to hear in the waiting room. If they don't like the question you ask, they accuse you of being rude.

author: NHS employee since 1986
title: This experience has really coloured our thinking
body:
Daughter had treatment here last month under general surgery department and the experience from start to finish was poor. She had exactly the same operation two years previously under orthopaedic surgery and the experience then was absolutely gold standard - astonished general surgery could be so bad.  
First all admission was fumbled - told to stay in, then told to go home. Consented by doctor for local anaesthetic as day case but when returned following day for this was reconsented for general anaesthetic and an inpatient stay. Because of change of plan had to wait in A& E waiting room for six hours until inpatient bed became available.  
During theatre procedure had unexpected bleed leading to 48 hours of low blood pressure (headaches, lightheadedness to boot). Despite bleed in theatre nurse on night shift then tried to administer IV blood thinners. On day after surgery nurse in charge did not know who my daughter's consultant was, so discharged home with no follow up appointment. No visit from pharmacist on day of discharge so sent home without antibiotics (walk in centre had to then remedy this in spite of the fact it is not their responsibility).  
Daughter in so much pain had to return to the A& E department at Chelsea and Westminster - however, they failed to bleep the surgical team so she went home feeling as bad as when she came. Would not use this hospital again for any kind of surgery (feel very bad for the orthopaedic department saying that but this more recent experience has really coloured our thinking).

title: Great practice
body: Very friendly, helpful staff quick to b seen smooth consultation throughout ,would recommend this surgery , easy to get to by car and what’s more plenty of parking space

title: Great practice - thanks to all at Sunnyside!
body: Our family have used the surgery quite a lot in the last year for our kids immunisations and other bits and pieces. Throughout Covid they have been consistently contactable, responsive and very caring in their approach. It must be a challenging time for all the staff so I want to say a big THANK YOU for all you do. It is much appreciated!

title: Let down twice, too hard to actually see a…
body:
Don't know what the actual service is like because twice now i've attempted to begin the process and twice i've felt left in the cold.

The first was just under 2 years ago, i had to complete a training program for a week before being allowed to access therapy, I suffer from ptsd which flared up and i missed 2 days, i was then removed from the service and told i would have to start it again from scratch. To someone who was struggling to survive my environment and symptoms, this was a big blow to my mental health, i spiralled downwards and couldn't face going through the entire process again.

More recently I've been trying to enquire about a bipolar diagnosis, and i was referred to think wellbeing halton again. The person i spoke with initially was lovely, we did an hour long triage session and although we talked about things that were hard to discuss, they were understanding and supportive. 

The next step in the process was a phone appointment. I was rang about 40 minutes late, and unfortunately i hadn't slept in 30 hours due to ptsd/insomnia. i explained the situation and said i can't discuss heavy things because im so tired i cant think straight, is it possible to get a call back the next day. I was told no it wasn't possible, and once again i was removed from the service. I rang back a few days later to try and rebook, but i was told i'm going to have to once again start from scratch, including another hour long triage call to discuss the same traumatic things that i'd already discussed just a few days before. The thought made me feel ill, so i cancelled the new triage appointment.

Twice now I've felt abandoned by the service, and being cut off so quickly brought up a lot of past abandonment trauma. Some of the people are nice but they also seem to be unapologetic about removing vulnerable people from the service. I was borderline suicidal the first time I got in touch, i said i wasn't because admitting it can get you put in hospital, but i was still counting on this therapy service to survive. I recovered on my own after a failed attempt, i just wish i could have gotten the therapy I needed before hand.

I'm upset because it can be hard to keep appointments and follow instructions with bad mental health problems, and vulnerable people need to be supported and understood rather than cut loose and sent back to square 1. If you're in a bad place its hard enough to seek help in the first place, having to pass these additional roadblocks can have devastating consequences to vulnerable and suffering people. I understand that we don't live in an ideal world and resources are limited, but a bit of support and understanding could well save lives.

Please bear in mind this isn't a review of the actual therapy, it might well be great, i just needed to let someone know the minor issues i've faced with this service have had some major impacts on me. The feelings of abandonment have put me off the entire service,and i doubt i'll try them again now.

title: Fantastic Practice
body:
I have been a patient of this practice for years. My parents were too. Doctors nurses health care assistants all staff work has a team.  I recently had some stitches removed and the safety for patients and staff during the pandemic is exceptional.  At the moment we use online triage that is done through the website or patient access . It is easy to do and you are contacted within two days. In my experience it’s been the same day and have had a telephone consultation. If people have no internet or can not use the computer or the elderly you can still ring the practice. My online triage experience has been excellent. I have been very ill due to Covid and other health problems. I can honestly say the care and support I have had from all staff is outstanding.  Reception staff are helpful and caring when they ring you. During these difficult times I can honestly say I am lucky to have a fantastic practice that work as a team and I have found the online triage helpful because phone lines can be busy and if you need to speak or see a doctor the online triage works well.  You Are notified of a call back by text  and if the g p feels you need to be seen then they can arrange a safe face to face appointment using strict safety guidelines.
This practice is a team and that makes a huge difference .  The phone lines can be very busy but I know they are looking into putting in a new system . Thank you to everyone at this caring Practice

title: Receptionists poor attitudes
body:
The receptionists here for years on end are always rude and have always had  serious attitude problems. They never sound like they actually care about you and consistently try to get you off the phone as soon as possible whether you get the help you need or not. They will have you on hold for longer than half an hour with no apology or anything  you’d think during coronavirus they would be more caring but no. Management definitely know of this problem there are several complaints of the same thing on Google reviews of the practise and they give the same typical replies to it such as “this is not our standards” and “we will be talking to staff” but that’s as unhelpful as the responses the receptionists give with no real action plan on how they are going to improve - not hard to see where they get it from.

The service you get from the doctors is fantastic and second to none, always willing to help and listen to you. It’s just a shame this will always be overlooked by the receptionists.

Seriously whoever is in management at this practise If you read this review please put a action plan to how receptionists should speak and deal with customers because I don’t want to hear a general copy and paste reply. In fact, why don’t you test call them yourself to see the service you’d get as a patient and I guarantee you’d even shock yourself. They sound so unbothered and have a consistent tone of voice that says ‘why are you calling me?’. If you don’t believe me or think it’s a one off check the reviews of the practise on Google. This is the last chance I’m giving this practise before I leave for good.

As mentioned, if you manage to past through the war over the phone with the receptionists, doctors are awesome. Nurses are really great too. Very professional and caring.

author: Rones
title: Physiotherapy
body: Treated with the highest standard of care by Dominika, great patient care she listened to my concerns and gave me the appropriate exercises to help strengthen my arm, 110% satisfaction, keep staying safe all of you thank you Nhs x

author: thebeak
title: Dermatology Treatment
body:
I had a skin biopsy in November 2020 at the Dermatology Department based in Stirling Community Hospital. The procedure was performed by specialist nurses David and Angela. Both were very professional and operated as a well established team . Throughout the procedure I felt that I was the focus of their attention and altogether is was a pleasant experience.  
I appreciate that the NHS is enduring severe pressures at this time but the skills of the staff referred to above must be recognised and appreciated. Thanks for the excellent care.

author: scorpiusbk68
title: Looked after me so well
body: I use the Haematology department at Barnstaple hospital and everything they do is exemplary.   They look after me so well even when I have phone appointments

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: alabama
title: Great birth experience at BGH
body:
I gave birth at BGH to my second child.  
My community antenatal appointments were great, despite difficulties due to Covid. However it is a real shame the local midwife resources have been removed from our village and I had to drive 40 minutes for each appointment. I imagine it would be difficult for first time mums to have fewer appointments and could feel less supported, and for those who rely on public transport as it is sparse in our area and an appointment could end up taking a whole day. I called the labour ward on the day when things started and received good support in making my own decision over the phone with regards to when to go in vs staying at home. I felt supported and reassured at that point. Although I wasn't sure about current Covid-related guidelines and had to ask, it would have been good to have been informed at that point about the current rules for masks, partners etc. I had been told the most up to date information at my last antenatal appointment, but things change so fast I wasn't sure it would be the same.When we went in we were welcomed and made to feel comfortable. I felt listened to, not judged or made to feel silly at all about any of my thoughts or preferences about labour or birth. I had a quick labour and gave birth within about 50 min of arriving. I was asked how I was doing at intervals in an open and unobtrusive manner, and felt I could ask for what I needed when I needed it. I'm not sure the midwife believed me when I said I felt I was progressing and the baby was coming, but she reacted quickly and appropriately when it came! A student nurse was also present throughout. Her presence was great, she was lovely, seemed keen to learn and in no way detracted from the experience.After the birth we had plenty of time to be alone in the room with our new baby, for skin to skin, feeding and just being together. As the baby and I were both fine this was straight after the birth, the assessments and sutures were left a little while. My partner also got time for skin to skin while I showered. This was really special and probably the highlight of the experience for us both. We then went to the ward, as it was late and we live a good distance from the hospital we were given a side room and they had made a bed up for my partner, which was really appreciated and made all the difference.It is worth mentioning I also gave birth to my first child at BGH in 2018. The experience then was also fantastic. The midwife when I was in labour was great, supportive and respectful. She was particularly confident (in an entirely appropriate, understated way) in what to do/not to do for me. I didn't need to ask for anything, she seemed to anticipate what I needed. I basically tried to replicate the atmosphere she created for my second birth! Later however, my partner had had to leave, late at night after being awake for over 40 hours and through a stressful and emotional experience, to drive over an hour home. This spoiled the experience then a bit as it was actually dangerous and he had to stop to sleep at the side of the road on the way. I stayed overnight the first time, rather than going home as early as I could have. I felt this made a huge difference as I could ask all the simple things I didn't know as a first time mum such as how to change a nappy, bath the baby, check the baby was latched on etc. Little things that could have caused a fair amount of stress if I was at home without that extra support initially. It was just a shame my partner wasn't given any consideration.  
Both experiences have been great overall. In particular, what makes it is that the staff have been friendly, helpful and respectful, at all hours. I would happily return in the future if a third came along!

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

title: general
body: Nurse practitioner friendly & helpful appreciate health check & urine test and went through family history and took accurate notes

title: Satisfactory experience
body: Very friendly greeting. Very efficient nurse. Stark reception area. Impossible to get through on the phone but website response was efficient.

title: This hospital has my trust
body:
I got admitted into hopsital with severe covid 19 on Sunday
Got moved from 1 ward to another, can't remember where I stayed apart from ward 515.
But everywhere I went, the staff were excellent which is good when you're scared stiff of hospitals like myself.
All staff should be very proud of what they do!

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Wonderful Staff.
body: All staff are warm and  welcoming I’ve never felt so comfortable going into hospital. I felt at ease throughout my procedure and that I was part of the decisions made about my care.

title: Kind and dedicated staff
body:
I recently required several blood tests. As a, difficult to access blood patient, I was anxious about the process in the new marquee. I need not have worried, the kind staff supported me throughout giving me assurances I wasn’t causing them any worries and they managed to use their professional skills to extract the required blood samples. 
A difficult task, well done professionally with a tactful, humerus approach. Thank you

title: Excellent female GPs
body:
I tried to leave a positive review last year when having a coil fitted but it was rejected as I included the Doctors name - having received very good care once again it reminded to me to try again with a review! Despite the challenges of covid this is an excellent GP practice, the receptionists really make an effort to help, fantastic nurses and brilliant GPs. On female services such as smear test, contraception, coil fittings the female nurses and GPs go the extra mile to make you at ease and as comfortable as possible. I mainly see two female GPs at the practise, their level of care, thoroughness and taking the time to diagnose and treat is exemplary. I had a bad kidney infection and they pre-arranged to ring me to check on my symptoms, wonderful care and the NHS at its best. 

I don't always agree with how First 4 Health Group is run and the behaviour and decisions of the senior Partner, but the actual team of nurses, GPs and reception staff are amazing and they do so much to support the health of the local community - thank you for everything you all do.

author: Rose704
title: Professional Physiotherapy
body:
I needed support with appliances in my bathroom and toilets.  
I was pleasantly surprised at how quickly I received an appointment with Debbie.  
Debbie was very professional, and made me feel at ease, as though she was just one of the family! WELL DONE DEBBIE!

author: Croydon resident disappointed
title: MRI Scan - complete lack of confidentiality/dignity/privacy
body:
I attended an MRI scan today and was very sad to see what I saw.  
3 patients were at anyone time in the mobile MRI (container), 1 in the scan, 1 kept in the tiny changing cubicle (1metre x 2 metres with 3 lockers in there) siting on a chair (which is not being decontaminated at every use!) and finally 1 patient next to the nurses desk.  
This means that whilst waiting for one's turn, one can see the scan pictures on the nurses' computers (3 screens) as well as the name and details of person in the scan. One can also see the person, in the scan, in their hospital gown.  
In my opinion there was absolutely no concern from the staff for confidentiality, dignity or privacy. They were literally moving people one after the other like sheep!  
I was very fortunate that my scan was only for a limb so did not need to undress, but still, at least 2 other patients have seen by details and my scans...  
Not good at all ! The lack of confidentiality awareness is very disturbing and shocking!

author: Cebby
title: My Mum's journey through GRI
body:
My 87 year old mother was admitted to GRI mid July - she was initially admitted to HDU & ITU before being transferred to Ward 8 and Ward 30.  
It was a difficult time for the family, due to visiting restrictions as a result of Covid, but this was further compounded early September when all visiting was stopped.  
We then had to rely on phone calls / updates with ward staff and Facetime / Zoom video calls with Mum. The nursing staff on ward 30 were terrific - they would contact us whenever Mum was awake to do Facetime calls, and verbally update us with any progress Mum was making.  
My family and I thank all staff involved in the care of Mum, particularly the nursing staff of Ward 30 who seemed to intuitively make those calls to us for video contact with Mum. As difficult as it is for us during Covid restrictions you become aware that for the nursing staff they go above & beyond nursing care during these difficult times, they really got to know Mum.  
Speech & Language services, Physiotherapy & Medical staff demonstrated Multi disciplinary team working at it's best! Thank you all!

readBy.name: Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration
University of Glasgow - School of Medicine, Dentistry and Nursing

author: Lee89
title: Discharged myself
body:
It all started with blurred/tunnel vision and tension in my right eye. I spoke to an eye specialist who declared that my vision was fine but there was fluid behind the eye.  
  
They sent me to the medical department to see a doctor. After a 6-7 hour wait I decided I wanted to go home and told the receptionist I wanted to discharge my self.  
Instantly a doctor arrived and said that I have pressure on my brain which required a lumbar puncture. After another 1-2 hour wait I was told I would be staying over night and transferred to the S.A.U. At this point no one told me what was going on and how long I was going to be there for. 5-6 days later I’m still in the hospital and still with no more information, no doctor had come to see at any point to keep me informed as to what was going on. I was going to the nurse station at least twice a day to get some answers but nothing! At this point I was getting very upset and frustrated and wanted to go home, to which I started packing my bags and walked out, for a nurse to then chase me and say the doctor is here now.  
I seen the doctor and he told me what I already knew and decided to discharge my self. I honestly can’t believe it takes some one to walk out the hospital to actually get seen. I felt as though it was a waste of my time and there’s, not to mention me taking up a bed for 6 days when there is other patients that need it more than I do. I didn’t sign any paper work when I left and now I don’t know whether I will be having another lumbar puncture or not. Or will I be left in the dark again!  
I honestly think there is a serious lack of communication between staff and patients which I think needs addressing.

author: balloon
title: Breast care centre
body:
I just wanted to say that I was super impressed with the care I received this week from all those in the breast care centre. It was my first attendance, and I was like many women scared and concerned. From being met and greeted by a friendly receptionist, to the lively and caring HCA, through to the radiologist, surgeon and technicians. To be able to offer the full service...examanition by surgeon, ultrasound by radiologist, mammogram and diagnosis in just 1 hour, is fantastic! No waiting, no anxiety and worry dragged out over days or weeks. It was a brilliant patient experience. The environment was fresh and bright and welcoming too (I even commented on the jolly scrubs the nurses were wearing)...burried deep in the old building, the breast care centre is a breath of fresh air!  
many thanks

author: throwaway2768
title: Discharged after missing one appointment
body:
Waited 5 months for assessment without any updates after initially being told a maximum of a few weeks. I was then dropped from the service after missing a single appointment, despite making Inclusion aware of my difficulties. There had been no check-up, or warning. Just a letter a week later stating I’d been discharged.  
I personally feel this is absolutely disgusting. Being professionals in their field, they should know full well those with mental illness are going to have difficulties and may require extra care with things such as attendance etc. They should be working to help those struggling, not chucking them away at the first hurdle.  
I can’t recommend Inclusion after my personal experience.

author: casacumbre
title: Ulcerative colitis -no phone call
body:
Finding it impossible to get a GP appointment and suffering a severe bout of Ulcerative Colitis I contacted the Gastroenterology dept. at Shrewsbury hospital where I have been treated before. The nurse phoned back and I explained the situation. The nurse I spoke to said they would phone me back after speaking to a consultant. After 3 days and another message left I have no medication, symptoms that are debilitating and am unable to retain food or fluid for any length of time.  
Just do not know what to do next!

readBy.name: Shrewsbury and Telford Hospital NHS Trust

author: Sad times
title: Attitude of staff during pandemic
body:
In late March 2020 I unexpectedly discovered I was pregnant; the same time as the national pandemic was introduced.  
I was in shock and wasn’t sure how far along the pregnancy was. During the April bank holiday I began to experience light bleeding and acute pain in my lower abdomen, my partner suggested I contacted my GP. At this point my GP would not see any patients face to face so I had a telephone appointment. My GP expressed concern about the symptoms I was experiencing and advised me to present at Liverpool Womens Hospital A&E immediately. Fortunately I had a friend to drive me there. I felt frightened, vulnerable and upset, I could not stop crying. On arrival at the Women's Hospital I had to approach alone ,with my friend parking a 5 mins walk away from the entrance. I was confronted by a security officer who told me I could not go into the hospital and loudly asked me why are you here anyway. I explained I had been sent under the guidance of GP, crying, I read a small note on the hospital door saying A&E was appointment only with a phone number attached. I immediately began to ring this number which continued to ring out. After 5 minutes of the phone ringing out, I was still standing outside and still very emotional, I asked the security guard to assist me, they told me to cheer up and smile. Eventually they agreed to let me present at the main reception. Again at reception I was confronted by 2 more security officers; luckily a nurse saw how upset I was and offered to help me. I explained my situation to them and although they showed me kindness the fact I had to disclose this in the main foyer was less than comfortable. The nurse phoned through to the a&e team.Within a minute a nurse presented to me, they were covered in PPE so I could hardly make out what they were saying and when I asked them to repeat what they had said they shouted across the foyer “why have you turned up here?” I was clearly emotional. I explained my GP had sent me and the nurse replied (again in the foyer) “Thats not true its a bank holiday, no GP is open, so why are you here” I then had to explain in the main foyer my situation and she said “you shouldn’t be here” it was only when I asked what else I was meant to do the nurse told me to follow them. I was then placed in a side room and left alone for 10 minutes. After then the same nurse returned and abruptly asked me for my name which they wrote on a scrap of paper. Nothing else said I was again left alone for 5-10mins. On their return the accused me of not being in the system. I confirmed my details and it transpired the nurse had written my name incorrectly. Again I was left alone for a longer period this time and during which another nurse entered the room, ignoring me and took something from a cupboard. When the nurse returned they abruptly asked me to explain my symptoms/issue . I was an emotional wreck at this point but summoned the assertiveness to bring to the nurses attention that I was feeling vulnerable, and that they had not even introduced them self or explained anything to me in the time I’d been there. The nurse seemed taken a back but I did try to generalize this by saying the “pandemic is causing a lot of stress to nurses who should be at home” As I waited to see the doctor I requested a tissue and some water, with so much emotion I had none left. The nurse agreed but did not bring this to me.I eventually saw a doctor who was professional, helpful and empathic and dealt with my matter.I understand that the pandemic is causing all kinds of new stresses and challenges for both individuals and organizations. However I am so disappointed and disgusted at how this front line and nursing staff acted towards me as a clearly upset, vulnerable women alone at hospital. It really isn’t acceptable.It has taken me a long time to write this account but of course I never forget it.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: What is wrong
title: Outpatient appointment
body: Turned up in mid November 2020 for a dexta scan in the morning 20 minutes before my appointment time. I was told by a high vis wearing member of staff that I couldn't go in for 15 mins. Waited outside with a handful of other people, about 5 others. We was then told that we could go in. We all filed in and walk past a chair with a thermometer sitting on it. No one had a temperature check and then I walked through a bottle neck with people being forced to be very close to each other. Hopeful I will not have to visit Medway again.

author: Cmgreg
title: Visit to Lincoln County
body:
I waited for a telephone consultation for a good few months (thanks corona), and when I finally spoke to someone it was quick and easy. I suffer from interstitial cystitis where I get regular monthly treatments. These stopped in March. Today I had a cystoscopy to see how my bladder was. I usually have treatment at Grantham, and had my cystoscopy done there before, but this time it was at Lincoln.  
When I arrived the person at the main entrance couldn’t direct me where I needed to go as they didn’t know where it was, so I got forwarded to reception who said to follow the signs. Unfortunately, there are no signs for the urology investigation suite! I eventually arrived and met with a great group of staff. They checked me in and talked me through, making friendly conversation. I had a meeting with a nurse where I discussed my worries and fears and she forwarded my concerns onto Angie who was doing my procedure. Angie, Steve and the nurse talked me through the whole process and tried to keep me distracted and made sure I was comfortable throughout. Compared to the original trauma I suffered years ago at another hospital, Angie was so gentle and made a horrible procedure into an endurable one. Thank you to your urology investigation unit for all your help today.

author: Dedem
title: ENT appointment
body: Attended an ENT appointment for an Endoscopy. Although this was a little uncomfortable Dr Lefay and his nurse were extremely reassuring and made me feel completely at ease. All staff that I came into contact with during my visit were very pleasant and efficient. All Covid procedures were followed and I felt completely safe. Thank you so much for the excellent care.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Kirkie
title: Recent stay in lch Lincoln
body: Recently had to be admitted and 2 stents fitted. From the beginning, first responder arriving at my home till my discharge the care and service was 1st class. All staff fro those who keep hospital clean to those at the top although they have had a very trying and exhausting year still found the energy to make me feel special and safe. I would like to say a heart felt thank you to them all and ask there management team to find a little time to thank them and make them feel how special they are not just the staff at lincoln but all nhs staff nation wide thank you

links.id: safe and special at all times

author: ElizaR
title: Visit to Dermatology VHK
body:
Attended Dermatology twice in the past few weeks with my father who needs me with him as carer/decision maker due to frailty and cognitive decline. I would like to offer my heartfelt thanks for the beautiful experience on both occasions. The first visit was consultation only, and the nurse who came to get us was so lovely, changed the chair outside the consulting room to one with arms as she could see the difficulty getting Dad up from a chair. I was able to be with him throughout the consultation and the specialist nurse and Dr. Mitchell again, were very caring, polite and professional.  
His second visit was for a procedure undertaken with local anaesthetic. Again Dr Mitchell, and the student on placement were excellent. A very positive experience and although I was required to answer questions and sign on Dad's behalf, the staff made sure he was given the respect due and talked to him constantly.  
Thank once more and congratulations on excellent teamwork.

author: Grateful Jill
title: "Fantastic nurses in the Recovery room (green zone level 3) and on Sunderland Ward at Medway Maritime Hospital
body:
I was recently diagnosed with bowel cancer and within a very short period of time underwent colorectal surgery combined with a secondary precautionary procedure.  
Following surgery, I was moved to the recovery room where I ended up staying overnight due to bed availability issues. I cannot praise the care I received and the dedication shown by the recovery nurses highly enough. In particular my thanks go to recovery nurses Doreene and Marie who looked after me and to the ward sister who stayed 6 hours after her shift had ended to try and resolve the bed issue and then support her nurses.  
The following day, I moved to Sunderland ward and again I can’t praise the nurses who looked after me highly enough. Special thanks to Julie, Lizzy and the nurse who looked after me during the night but unfortunately I can’t remember her name.  
These nurses are a credit to their profession, working long hours in very difficult circumstances at present and at times dealing with rude patients but remaining at all times professional. These ladies made what has been a challenging and difficult time for me more bearable. Thank you

author: Female74
title: About the ambulance service
body: This morning 19th November 2020 I needed the ambulance service for myself and I just want to praise the two paramedics who came and attended to me where absolutely fantastic everything they done from start to finish can not fault them. They are an absolute credit to the service.

author: Orangeacer
title: Paediatric blood tests, Croydon University Hospital
body: Took my 7 year old son in for a blood test in the Willows unit this morning. The clinic was spotless and running exactly on time. The member of staff who took my son's blood was lovely and made him feel completely at ease. Couldn't have asked for better service - thank you!

author: Auntie Tat
title: 3 very caring nurses
body: I had to go into Lincoln hospital, the maternity unit, for a colposcopy  as a smear test had found pre cancerous cells in my cervix. To say that I was scared and nervous on the day was an understatement,   not particularly of the procedure as I had read everything that I had been sent, but of the result. The 3 nurses, Ellen, Ruth and Jess were more than wonderful, they really calmed me down, explained everything to me and then did the gentlest procedure that they could to get rid of the cells. They held my hand, literally, and kept me calm while explaining everything. They really put my mind at ease and went above any beyond anything that I could have expected. They are an absolute asset to the hospital. I cannot thank them enough for what they did for me.

author: Newry patient
title: Treatment in daisy hill rapid access clinic
body: I was referred after having a fall. The staff investigated everything thoroughly professionally and with care. I felt extremely well looked after and put at ease. My care within the NHS at A& , E and thus clinic has been much more than I could have expected especially in this time of covid. I hope you pass on my appreciation

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: JR8
title: Overnight stay
body: Had an overnight stay in ward 52. Overall care very good. Nurses responded when required.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: gooma
title: my daughter xray
body:
My daughter who has joint problems was sent for an xray by her gp. A girl called Gill in Radiology department of Monklands Hospital did the xrays. Due to her joint problem and pain her flexibility is not great. Gill was extremely patient and caring towards my daughter. My Daughter found her very cheerful and friendly.  
Gill was also teaching a student that day and my daughter said she was extremely informative . My daughter was able to tell me all about coning in for an xray that evening.  
All staff were wearing masks, apron and gloves .

author: Dustondave
title: My appointment with incorrect information
body:
I received my appointment letter for the spinal clinic which clearly stated that the venue was the Frank Radcliffe Clinic area B, it told me to bring the letter and book in at the reception desk.  
Upon arrival I was informed that the appointment was actually telephone appointment. This had not registered with me because of all the instructions directing me to attend in person.  
As it happened it made no difference and I was treated anyway.I had travelled from Northampton so I ask if the instructions can be made more clearly.  
My experience at KGH was excellent as usual.

readBy.name: Kettering General Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: charbe
title: Helping other teams and service users.
body:
I am a nurse that works for the Crisis Team in Peterborough, we were referred a service user who in the PAST worked with CGL in Cambridge. On assessment he spoke very highly of the team and found the work sheets and information sheets helpful. Recently moved out of area and working with CGL in Wisbech.  
Due to this I got in contact with the team to ask for some guidance around where I would find the resources so we could give the service user something he find effective and helpful.  
I rang the team and was passed to Eleanor, I would like to feedback that she was so effective, efficient, caring and compassionate. Eleanor made it so easy to help this service user, she responded quickly to me, went above and beyond by sending me some work sheets and other information that could be useful, it was all relevant and useful.  
Eleanor did not have to do any of this as I work for a different team in a different area but she did and helped make the service users care tailored to him, allowing for patient centred care to work.  
  
Extremely professional throughout all the communication. Absolute pleasure to deal with

author: RKH777
title: Home birth team
body: We were looked after wonderfully by the Fife home birth team. They answered all our questions with patience and grace. In particular, Paula was incredible. From the initial meeting she put my wife at ease and was respectful of our wishes and perfectly professional from the start of the process right through to the birth of our daughter. She really made it special for us and we can't thank her enough. There are things you can teach people but warmth, compassion and understanding are traits that truly wonderful people possess. Thank you Paula x x

author: Oatmeal3
title: Phobia of needles and needing a blood test.
body:
I have had a phobia of needles ever since I was 4 years old. I needed a blood test, and unfortunately, my doctors did not have any slots available. They said I needed to go to High Wycombe Hospital.  
The nurse I had was outstanding. I started explaining my phobia (and instantly got very emotional), and she listened to me and instantly made me feel relaxed by telling me that her son was the same and I wasn't the first nor would I be the last to come in with a phobia of needles. She took her time, reassuring me constantly that it would be okay. She explained what she was doing, but with such a gentle and caring attitude.  
[Very happy with 'Staff skills']  
  
I didn't get her name, but I hope she sees this and knows how much I appreciate everything she did for me. I've taken one step closer to overcoming my fear of needles because of your care and understanding. Thank you so much ☺️  
[Very happy with 'Staff attitude']
